description:
Can you remember who is hiding where? Join Papa Smurf and all his friends in a fun game of hide and seek! Flip over a card and find the matching figurine underneath one of the five cups. There’s more than one of each card so you still have a chance to find it’s match…even if it’s already been won by another player! It’s all the fun of classic memo…and more, in an easy to learn 3D game.

Available in Spain, Italy, France, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg.

A game designed by the famous Israeli writer Ephraim Kison, describing the bureaucracy around receiving a package from the Israeli post office in the late '60.

Players roll the dice, advance their markers on the board and follow the instructions while collecting all the necessary documents.

From the Box:

"From fun with a frog to a pirate at the party - there's a new surprise to find behind every window of the busy train...but will you remember where you saw it?

How to Play:  First fit the two engine pieces together, then add the carriages/cars.  Now fit the window pieces face down, at random, into the spaces.  Shuffle the cards and place the pack face down between the players.  Players take turns to turn up a card from the top of the pack and then "open" a window.  If the window matches the card, the player leaves the window open and keeps the card.  If not, the player must close the window and return the card to the bottom of the pile.  When all the windows have been opened, the player who has collected the most cards is the winner.  For a shorter and simpler game, play with fewer carriages/cars and take away the corresponding number of window and memory cards.

Contents:

5 thick train pieces
15 window pieces
15 memory cards

Educational Value:

A wealth of detail encourages observation
Develops concentration and memory

Play Value:

Amusing illustrations stimulate imagination and add to the fun
Increase the challenge by adding carriages /cars"

Another well done memory game for kids 3+

From the Game Box:

"An exciting and unusual colour-matching game which encourages sharing and co-operation."

This jigsaw/game includes two sets of rules, one for a cooperative game and one for competitive play.

Players take turns rolling a die which either adds pieces to their house (player mat) or to a central 'cloudburst' mat.

The object of the game is to complete your house before the cloud bursts!

Inwigilacja luksusowa is a sequel to the game Inwigilacja

Of course it is also a game about politicians who are trying to get support for their parties, by revealing their opponents' dirty secrets. It is a deduction game, similar to "The mystery of the Abbey", and it is a heavy satire on Polish parliament and government.

Home Page: http://www.kuzniagier.pl/szczegoly.php?grupa_p=4&przedm=902293 (Polish)

The game contains the following components:

- the board
- the deck of 55 cards
- the deck of 54 files cards
- 24 tokens
- 10 answer markers
- 5 pawns
- 1 die
- notebooks
- the rulebook

DICE Boxing is a downloadable game from Gen1400 Gaming.  You get over 1,000 boxers from the 1800s to today in over 10 different weight classes.  More boxers are also available for free download.

Every boxer is rated in numerous categories based on their real life statistics.  Boxers will perform in DICE Boxing just like they do in the ring.

Replay super fights or create your own league and or tournaments.  How would Ali have done against Marciano or Mike Tyson?  Pit any two fighters against each other.

DICE Boxing also has a career mode.  Create your fighter and earn points by winning fights and moving your way up the rankings.  Do you have what it takes to become a champion?

DICE Boxing uses everything from ring movement to strategies.  DICE Boxing can be played with the simple basic game version or add more options to the advanced version to get a simulation close to real life.

Grace A Dice Play 21

From the rulebook:

This is an enjoyable, easy to play game for children and adults at home, school, churches, parks, casinos and sports fields.

Even teams of up to 6 people are formed.  Plus a 'director' manages one or two teams.  A die is rolled to indicate the movement of the player.  The player is moved on a board AND around the seating of the table.

Play alternates until one team returns the the original seating.

The Mind-Bending Anagram Game

The mental work-out for grey matter! Part anagram puzzle, part charades contest, this game tests you and your team-mates as you seek to solve a tricky set of conundrums. Each player takes a turn, assisted where possible by other team members. All scores combine into a grand team total. Many hours of fun packed into a handy pencil box!

The old Pumpkin King has recently passed to the great beyond. 
there is a battle  being waged between his two heirs for control of the patch. Who will take the throne?   
 Pumpking is a 2 player abstract strategy game that was inspired by the ancient game Latrunculorum. 
Players face off on a grid 6 squares wide by 11 squares
long. Each army consists of a Pumpkin Prince, two bats and six pumpkin warriors. The three pieces move following different rules.

Paper Cricket was first devised by Luke Morris in 1993 as a child trying to pass the time on long car journeys. With the rules written down for the first time, Paper Cricket is now available, for free, to everyone.

Paper Cricket is a simple game that aims to provide a bit of entertainment if you’re stuck as a passenger on a very boring car/train/plane journey or when you’re stuck late at work with nothing but some paper, a pencil (or pen) and a dice. At its’ most simple you need nothing else.

Paper Cricket does NOT intend to perfectly simulate the ebb and flow of a cricket match BUT from experience it does enough to provide realistic scores, averages and statistics. Cricket, like baseball, is a game of statistics.

With simple play rules (and optional squad selection mechanics) it's a game to pick up and play wherever you are and whatever you're doing.

Your aim is to hike TWO* of the treacherous mountain peaks of the Split River Valley, claim the pouches of lost gold, and be the first hiker to return to Base Camp (or be the Hiker with the best state-of-resources in a drawn finish).

You and your opponents all have the chance to hinder each other's progress by planting forest barriers around the mountains. You also have access to resources which will remove these trees (your axes and chainsaws), or enable you to fly over them (using your helicopter flights).

The hiker who best utilizes these resources, including their food supplies, will ultimately win the game.

Flash flooding, quicksand, snowfalls, broken bridges, landslides and avalanches are just some of the unpredictable hazards you may have to encounter along the way!

Our advice is "Be prepared". Plan your own moves in advance and try predicting moves to be made by other hikers. One false move or miscalculation will often mean the difference between your win or a loss!

Ages +10


    Other game variants exist (i.e., players can decide before a game how many mountain peak treasures will constitute a win. We recommend TWO treasures as this equates to around 60 minutes of game-play for 3-4 players).
This is your typical fund raising Monopoly. This one is set at the University of Washington, known by locals as "U Dub" rather than U of W.  The University of Washington is in Seattle.

This is a tactical space combat game in the Warriors of the Dark Star: The Age of the Neutron Wars series, and includes the second edition rulebook for that game (as a series rulebook).

From a GFG catalog (reproduced verbatim):


        This "WD" Game pits the powerful Omega Ship Constitution Class against the Deadly Unruk Dreadnaughts of the N'Dridds and the Sumnul Betas. Scenarios such as the "Attack on the Outposts", "Seige of the Frontiers", "Plunder Raids of the Brain Slaves", etc. This is a detailed comparison of what occured in the BFA "Deliverance from Beyond the Stars".


 

        Geomorphic Map—Sections, Hardbacked, solid boards, each one 11x14 inches, can be combined into a 22x28-inch mapboard, or a 44x14-inch, 64x11-inch mapboard, or any other combination. The Boards here have 9 different kinds of Space Obstacles and Vortexes. The amazing thing about WD boards is that the four boards in this game can be connected to the mapboards of other WD games, and ALL WD GAMES have their boards so made that they can be interconnected with all the other WD versions. Counters are on 8 1/2 x 11-inch large sheets showing the weapons systems in detail that the silhouettes on the BFA counters only implied. THIS GAME CAN BE PLAYED BY ONE OR MORE PEOPLE (UP T0 11 can play). Each player handles one ship. Sun Slayers specializes in OutPosts, Beacons, Omega Ships, Monitors; all are enclosed and utilize the drama of the long-term duties of the Star Forces in the  defensive OutPosts that might be raided at any time to poke a hole into Federation territory, for Taal Battle Cruisers to rush through and how fast Thetan and Alliance ships can rush to the aid of the Defensive Line.

"Colonial Era Combat game: 1879 - 1929. French Foreign Legion, British Colonials, Germans SWA Troops, etc. Simple, fun wargame rules for backyard, beach or living room."

"The romantic tales of the French Foreign Legion, the drama of the hundred British regulars who held off 4,000 Zulu warriors at Rourke's Drift, the harsh battle of Khartoum - these are the stuff of legend. Sahara Sands is a fast-action battle game that enables you to replicate those days of tropical heat and adventure. You bring the toy soldiers, regular dice and kite string while we show you how it's done!"

Ratings are provided for seven types of weapons common to figures of this era: rifle (rolling block or bolt action), jezail (muzzle-loading rifle), revolver, spear, cannon/mortar, Gatling gun, and machine gun. Each weapon is rated for rate of fire, range, and damage.

Basic unit speeds are provided for different types of units and vehicles (foot soldiers, camel troops horsemen, wagons, tanks, trucks, etc.) Terrain effects on movement are also specified. The rules also cover officers/leaders, prisoners, forts, and the shock value of 'modern' weapons.

"Pirate Adventure Game. These is a very simple game for play on beach or in backyard, with plastic toy soldiers. The focus is on a fast-action game, easy to learn and easy to play. Our game is for small battles, only - with forces of 100 men or less on each side."

There are fourteen types of characters specified in the rules. These include pirates ("the heroes of our game"), tow militia, the Navy, Marines, Moors, Conquistadors, Privateers, Indians, South Pacific Natives, and Samurai.

There are seven types of ranged weapons specified in the rules: Long Rifle, Pistol, Musket, Bow, Cannon, Light Cannon, and thrown weapons (spear, hatchet, tomahawk, marlinspike, etc.) Each weapon is rated for range, damage, and rate of fire.

Concepts covered in the rules include boarding, prisoners, ports, treasure, and the effect of tides and wind on boats. Campaign suggestions are also included.

One of the Jersey Shore Battle Games, available for free online

"Rules for American Revolution and the Alamo. These is a very simple wargame for play on beach or in backyard, with plastic toy soldiers. The focus is on a fast-action game, easy to learn and easy to play. Our game is for small battles, only - with armies of 100 men or less on each side."

"We have taken into account such things as flintlock pistols and the differences between muskets and rifles. (In this era, rifles could not be fitted with a bayonet! Only muskets had the bayonet attachment!)"

The players must supply the appropriate toy soldiers. The rules divide the figures into five types: Infantry (foot soldiers), Cavalry (mounted soldiers), Artillery (gun crewmen and cannons), Rangers (infantry with rifles), and Indians (who fight as infantry or cavalry).

Each type of figure is rated or movement, as are wagons and caissons. Six types of ranged weapons commonly found with Revolutionary War miniatures are rated for range, damage, and rate of fire. Other concepts covered in the rules include terrain effects, hand-to-hand combat, walls/bunkers, forts, and soldiers fighting as units.

"Medieval and Ancient Warfare. A simple, basic game based on warfare in ancient times. Easy to learn, easy to use, for backyard, beach or living room. Uses almost any size or type figures, from plastic toy soldiers to collectible miniatures."

The figures are divided into a variety of classes: Infantry (with distinctions based on level of armor), Cavalry (light and heavy), Charioteers, War Wagons, Siege Crews, Archers, and Hakenbuschers (including Arquebusiers and Musketeers).

Each type of figure is rated for movement and each type of weapon is rated for range, rate of fire, and impact (at short, medium, and long range).

Basic castle siege rules are included. Advanced rules cover formations and morale, as well as offering further distinction to various historical units and projectile weapons.

"The Jersey Shore Battle Games [previously known as the Sandy Hook Battle Games] are a group of simple, easy-to-play miniature battle games developed for one purpose: FUN! Unlike conventional board and miniature games, Jersey Shore Battle Games dispense with complexities altogether. Our goal is to provide a game that can be set up and played spontaneously, without studying complicated rules or spending extra money for expensive miniatures. Everything has to be commonly available."

The components required for play are kite string, two six-sided dice, a sand pail, a cup, a disk segmented into quarters (i.e. lines marked on a paper plate), and the appropriate toy figures.

The basic system rules are available for free.

The following games use the Jersey Shore Battle Games rules system:


    Castle Cracker
    Muskets and Sandpiles
    Operation Sandtrap
    Planetary Sand
    Sahara Sandstorm
    Sandarticus
    Sandpit Showdown
    Tanegashima Sandman
    Treasure of Sandheap

A miniatures air combat game based around the author's rudimentary homemade biplane miniatures which use a plastic soda bottle-cap as a base.

Movement is measured in inches, with the distance moved based on the roll of one to four six sided dice. The basic planes move 2d6 inches each turn. The number of dice or distance rolled will be modified if the aircraft dives, turns, or performs special maneuvers (stall, climb, barrel roll, or loop).

Combat is resolved by the attacker rolling machine gun dice and the defender rolling maneuverability dice. For the basic planes, each player rolls 3d6, with a hit being scored if the attacker rolls a higher total. A plane is shot down after taking six hits.

Advanced rules cover gun jams, sun position, rear gunners, custom planes, pilot skill levels, and damage effects.

Variant rules suggestions are included for Star Wars dogfights.

The Great Crusade is a roll-and-move game which starts as a puzzle and a big cardboard castle/tower. The players construct the board by putting together the puzzle, and then roll-and-move to see who gets to the dragon's hiding place first.
The Castle constitutes the game box, and the whole package is called The Enchanted Castle Adventure Play Set. Included are rules for "The Memory Game", using the cards and tokens.

Space Alert is a cooperative team survival game. Players become crew members of a small spaceship scanning dangerous sectors of the galaxy. The missions last just 10 real-time minutes (hyperspace jump, sector scan, hyperspace jump back) and the only task the players have is to protect their ship.

During play, the central computer will announce the presence of various threats on one of the supplied 10 minute soundtracks that also acts as a game timer. The threats vary from space battleships and interceptors to different interstellar monsters and abominations, asteroids or even intruders and malfunctions on the spaceship. Players have to agree who will take care of which task and coordinate their actions (moving around the ship, firing weapons, distributing energy, using battlebots to deal with intruders, launching guided missiles, etc.) in real time to defend the ship. Only a well-working team can survive 10 minutes and make the jump back to safety.

The game offers several difficulty levels, huge variability and a unique experience for one to five player teams. One mission lasts only about 30 minutes, including setup and evaluation.

(Based on a description from Czech Games Edition)

Spider uses a system of movement and jumping similar to that of Chinese Checkers, but with a twist.

The first playing piece (or 'fly') to cross the "Goal Line" at the other side of the board becomes the Spider and is placed in the center of the board. On subsequent turns, the Spider player may move the Spider in addition to their normal move.

Once the spider has collected a number of flies equal to the number of opposing players, the Spider is returned to its place at the opposite Goal and another player may become the spider simply by being first to move a fly into the center of the board. Captured flied are returned to their starting spaces when the current Spider 'retires'.

Another difference is that movement (and jumping) around the Spider's lair in the center of the board may be made in either direction.

Play continues until one player succeeds in moving all of their flies past the opposing Goal.

This odd game was published in Ocean Beach - a community of San Diego, California.

"Super Juegos" was a pioneer Spanish magazine about both, board and computer games, which was published between 1984-1985. Every issue included a board game inside, with rules and cut-out counters. As far as I know only eight numbers were published, at least in its first epoch (another publication with the same name would appear years later, this time focusing on computer games only).

"Severiano" (named after the famous Spanish golf player Severiano Ballesteros), was included in issue 2 and was obviously a golf match simulation. Players had to provide two counters (representing balls) and two dice, plus pencils and paper to note scores. Dice rolling determine the movement of the counters, while several terrain features affect movement in different ways.

From the back of the box:
"Now you too can play the snooker star's favourite red hot TV quiz game anytime.  Answer a question right and it's your turn to do some serious "potting".  Answer it wrongly and you're snookered.  Simply throw the dice and remember big throws could mean Big Breaks!"
Based on a hit early 90's BBC1 TV show in the UK hosted by Jim Davison and the snooker legend John Virgo.

Palago is a tile placement game in which players strive to form closed groups of their colour. Two players, White and Blue, share a common pool of 48 hexagonal arch tiles. Each tile contains a white arch and a blue arch, and may be oriented in three ways such that the corner colours are the same for each rotation.

White starts by placing two adjacent tiles, then players then take turns adding two adjacent tiles such that edge colours match neighbouring tiles.

The game is won by the player who forms a surrounded island of their colour containing at least one arch. If a move forms winning groups for both players, then the mover loses.

The fun fair has arrived in town, and Bumper Cars are the main attraction! The Bumper Car Autodrome is run under the watchful eye of a grumpy operator. For thrills and entertainment, only courageous and brave souls dare drive these bumper cars. With your band of young punks, you must prove to the world that you can drive better than your opponent, and claim the best part of the track for you and your team.
Players drive bumper cars for their respective teams. The basic principle of the game is to push other cars out of the way in order to be in a better scoring position at the right time. The corrupt operator rampages through the Autodrome while busily maintaining the bumper car attraction in perfect working condition. Both teams try to convince the operator to give them unfair advantages.
From time to time, the operator has to repair the overhead grid. Damaged grid sections are marked by signal bells. If a bumper car hits any of the bells, the car is expelled and the grid must be repaired. The operator immediately assesses the position of all cars to determine if a car is traversing a section currently under repair. If so, that car becomes disabled.
Players score points by placing & keeping their cars on higher-value sections and by pushing their opponent’s cars onto lower-value sections of the Autodrome. A player can also score points by pushing an opponent‘s car off the track.
In order to maximize the fun and to keep the game entertaining and challenging, the operator reassembles the Autodrome in a new configuration prior to the start of each game of "Crash by Crash."

A square-shaped board with 13 slits (axes) crossing it is placed in the center of the table. A square-shaped card is drawn from a deck and placed onto the board. The card covers the entire board except for the ends of the axes, leaving room for a mirror to be inserted into the axes perpendicular to and on top of the card. The card displays several spheres that are red, green, yellow, or blue.

Players race to choose which of the 13 axes they think the mirror should be inserted into so as to produce the most points when all the reflected and actual spheres are counted. A player cannot choose an axis that another player has chosen. Once all the players have made a selection, the mirror is inserted in turn into each chosen axis. The player who chose a particular axis decides which direction the mirror should face when inserted into that axis. The axis scores for the player who chose it. Each green sphere adds a point, and each yellow sphere subtracts a point. The player also adds points equal to the difference between the number of red and blue spheres.

Play continues with a new card. The game ends when one player reaches an agreed-upon point total.

Race Across America is a free download game from Gen1400 Gaming.  You can download Race Across America from www.gen1400.com.

In Race Across America (RAA) you compete with other players racing across states.  Pick and choose which states you would like to race in or draw some randomly.

RAA is not just a racing game.  Before you go on to the next state you will have to complete a challenge.  The Challenge could be as easy as rolling an even number or as hard as rolling a 5.

RAA is a fun family game that is also educational.  Each state is represented by a card.  The State's capital is also listed on every state card.

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Each player takes the role of 1 or more successive 20th century Dictators."

The game uses a custom deck composed of five types of cards: Challenge cards, Military Power cards, Political Power cards, Atrocity cards, and Wealth cards. Players score Victory Points for playing Political Power, Atrocity, and Wealth Cards.

"The game ends when a turn starts and there are no cards left in the deck. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins."

Imagine yourself as a mighty-thewed barbarian, raised in the hill country of Njorden or a loyal Captain of the Lion Guard of Ibyssia, or even a powerful sorcerer in the service of Mök. Broadsword Adventures transports you to the land of Tauren where ancient secrets lie buried in lost cities, powerful necromancers seek to enslave the kingdoms of men, and around every turn there is a chance become a hero of legend or suffer ignoble defeat.

Broadsword Adventures contains all the rules necessary to play the game as well as more than two dozen archetypes to build characters, a section on designing your own scenarios, a campaign system so your characters can advance as they adventure, and five complete scenarios so that you can start playing right away.

The archetypes presented are detailed enough to make them different from one another, but generic enough that you can use these rules to fit any world you want to game in; from your own custom-designed lands to an already established setting.

Whether you want to play this as a miniatures game, a board game, or a light roleplaying game, the mechanics are easy enough and flexible enough to suit your needs.

So sharpen your blade and don your armor as you prepare for Broadsword Adventures!

124 Pages

A Trivia-Game about Partnership, Fun, Tears and Happiness.
Join together with any other player to move faster to the Final Question. By using characters from your horoscope you have to know your partners very good.

The objective of the game is to build a build a big cube (3x3)using little ones (1x1). The first player who finishes the cube wins.
The small cubes are in two colours, black and white, so you can't have a small cube next to another one of the same colour.
Once the player placed some small cubes to build the big one ha can not remove them.

El juego consiste en que cada jugador debe montar un cubo grande (3x3) a base de cubitos (1x1). El primero que lo consiga gana el juego.
Los cubitos son de dos colores, negro y blanco, no se pueden usar dos cubitos del mismo color juntos en el cubo grande.
Una vez se han colocado cubitos en el cubo grande no se pueden mover ni quitar.

The Future Art of War is a science fiction wargame, self-published by Leonard J. Meloche.

The game map consists of 26 planets (one starting with each letter of the alphabet).

Players start with one planet, and a small force of ships.  They occupy/conquer planets, collect and trade resources, build ships, supply their planets and attempt to discover Battleship technology.

Players are eliminated when their home planet is conquered, and victory is achieved through the elimination of all other players.

The Future Art of War includes a creative movement mechanic which adds to the "fog of war" effect.  Ships travel from planet to planet via "hyperspace", and a chart indicates the number of turns (1-6) required to travel between each pair of planets. When a ship departs for a planet, the controlling player secretly writes the first letter of the planet and the number of turns required on the bottom of the ship counter, and places it on the first space in the hyperspace track.  Each turn, all ships in the hyperspace track move one space further down the track, and, when a ship has reached the appropriate space, the controlling player reveals the ship's destination.  Therefore, while players know how many ships their opponents have in hyperspace, they do not know the ships' destinations, or when they will arrive.

The components of this game are quite good for a self-published game.  The map is poster-quality, and the cards, reference sheets, and money are comparable to many commercially published games.  The one component that clearly identifies the game as "self-published" is the ship counters, which are cut rectangles of flat plastic.  These, however, with a whiteboard marker, serve the "hyperspace" mechanic very well.  The game is packed in a large tube.

The game is played in rounds. In each round, a planet is picked. Players then try to conquer that planet by deploying the largest amount of troops. A conquered planet earns victory points. When Coruscant, the galaxies capital planet, is conquered, the game ends and the player with the highest victory point total wins.

Troops are represented by cards; each card has one of six colors and a number from 1 to 5 on it. A set of cards of the same color can be deployed as the force trying to conquer a planet. The total sum of the numbers printed on these cards is the troop's strength. The strongest army wins the planet, earning 2 to 4 victory points for the player who deployed that army.

Since the game is based on 2008's "Clone Wars" animated TV series, some characters from the series are featured as "generals". For each color, there is a Jedi/Sith leader or general that can be earned during the game and then played to add a +3 troop bonus. Available leaders are Commander Cody, Yoda, General Grievous, Anakin Skywalker, Asaj Ventress and Obi-Wan Kenobi.

At the end of each round, players rally new troops from the card deck to conquer the next planet.

The gameplay is rather quick and simple, strategic options are limited, and some luck is involved in getting matching colored cards from the card deck.

There is an alternate name for this game: "Sith gegen Jedi" (Sith vs. Jedi).

Starfighter Combat is a mass combat game.
 A game of tactics and intuition, players strive to out-maneuver and out think their opponents in Star fighter
combat. The players may control single Star fighters or entire squadrons. The rules are flexible enough for multi-player combat and more detailed scenarios.

In this game each Star fighter has attributes:  
Max Speed, Speed, Impetus, Armor and Shields.

You use cards to control your ships movement.

The game includes ship building rules, and many different ships already made. 


Free from:
http://www.geocities.com/shaungamer88/sfc.htm

Traveling Game with more than 1.000 Questions concerning the 80s.
MUSIC-LIFESTYLE-HAPPENINGS-TV and CINEMA-SPORTS-CULTURE
Who knows the answers to 7.200 questions? Nice Party-Game for players who love to answer very hard questions.

Solitaire tactical American Civil War game re-creating the battle of Cold Harbor near Richmond, VA from May 31-June 12, 1864.

Reprinted in a separate (ziplock) printing from its original appearance in Panzerschreck #3 (1999) as "Cold Harbor II" with map, counters and rules that "are slightly modified from the original edition". Reprinted again in 2015 in Panzer Digest #12 as "Assault at Cold Harbor" with color map and counters and updated rules.

Description: The player (Union) makes a frontal assault against entrenched Confederate positions in the hope of achieving a breakthrough.

Drivers from all over Europe have arrived and are lined up on the starting line. Consisting of narrow and winding roads, the track is filled with dangers and promises a tricky race. As one of the fastest and fearless pilots in the race, you will try to pass the finish line before your opponents by being the quickest at spotting and grabbing the die which will allow you to move forward.

Hurry'Cup is a car racing game where 3 to 6 players face off on tracks that are always different from one game to the next; as decided by the players themselves. Reflexes, dexterity, and risk-taking are the key to stepping first on the podium. It is a tile game with pavement-burning ambiance. Made up of 36 modular tiles, the Hurry'Cup race track offers many game possibilities, making it a new game each time. Hurry'Cup is a game with simple rules and Fast and Furious Fun.

Witch of Salem is a cooperative boardgame based on Wolfgang Hohlbein's book series which in turn is based on H.P. Lovecraft's mythos.
In this game, the players attempt to close all the gates to the other dimensions that have opened in Arkham city and thus preventing the Old One from entering our world. Players need to banish monsters and collect items in order to seal the eight gates before time on the doom-tracker runs out and the Great Old One awakens.

The gameplay follows three steps in a fixed order: bringing new creatures in the game, the player actions and drawing an event card.
The game can be won by succesfully by completing different goals: find out the active Great Old One, seal all eight gates and send a player with the right combination of items to the Great Old One to banish him.
Losing the game can be done in three different ways: the doom track runs out, the players fail to reveal the Great Old One in time or the players all go insane.

From the publisher:

Step back to early 20th Century New England. Here, the horrible "Great Old Ones" mysterious inhabitants of a dark, unfathomable void-seek entry into our world. One of their imprisoned overlords gathers them, just as his worldly servants open portals throughout Arkham for the coming onslaught. Only Salem's master witch, Robert Craven, holds the key to safeguarding mankind. He plans to gather a team of intrepid scholars to find the hidden portals and close them with powerful magic seals. The noble witch's elite team must battle the threat of madness, duel the dark servants, tackle mystical challenges, and face their ultimate nemesis: an unidentified Great Old One with an unknown and incalculable strength.

In "Witch of Salem," you step into the terrifying world of renowned storyteller Wolfgang Hohlbein, a mythos inspired by the tales of H. P. Lovecraft. You play one of the witch's scholarly allies. Working cooperatively with your cohorts, uncover the secrets of the Necronomicon, combat creeping insanity, defeat the coming Evil, and bar the Great Old Ones from exiting the inter-dimensional abyss.

Contains:
1 game board, 4 game figures, 1 witch figure, 1 Necron Stone, 1 battle die, 26 creature cards, 6 Great Old One cards, 12 event cards, 6 overview/turn cards, 32 minor location cards, 4 player boards, 34 item markers, 4 sanity markers, 6 artifact markers, 8 portal tiles, 1 cloth bag, game rules, brief history

After a trip to Isla de Pascua (Easter Island), the author brings to us this game based on the inhabitants of the island and the extinction of them.

The Rapa-Nui tribes were isolated about 1000 years in a remote, tiny and volcanic island. There were a lack of resources and the population lived in a unstable balance with the environment, the rivalry between tribes and the collective society.

THE GAME

Players manage the building of the 'moais' (these big sculptures with big faces, facing to the sea), using quarries, men, palm trees (to take wood) and even 'slaves'.

I had heard from some testers that the mechanics of the game were very similar to Puerto Rico, but the only similarity is the 'role selection' phase.

The game is only available (rules and components) for Print & Play at: http://kokorin.wordpress.com/2008/06/15/rapa-nui/

La Soupe Ã  Gertrude (Gertrude's soup) is a game where each players are trying to obtain enough ingredients to make their soup first. There are 5 types of ingredients in the deck of cards, you only need 3 differents.

The current player pick the 3 top cards of the deck, choose one that will be face up, the others face down. Now (in no specific order), all the players bid on the lot. Once the winning bid has been found, that player will pay the other players by giving them cards for the total bidded, then pick up the lot. If he has 3 different ingredients, he wins.

The aim of the game is to collect 10 cocoa, 10 tea and 10 vanilla tokens.
Players move using a die into several production areas in order to collect tokens and deliver them.
If there is a green spot on a production area, player must take an event card.
Components:
A board, 6 players token, 6 delivery cards, 180 goods token, 1 vanilla perfume bottle.

The magical search for the butterflies …

There is trouble in fairy land. Just as they were getting ready for the annual fairy ball, an evil wizard placed a spell on all the fairies. Suddenly they can’t find their way to the castle, and the fairy ball is in danger. Fortunately, there are the butterflies – they know the way. But all the butterflies are sleeping, hidden beneath colourful leaves. Will you help Feelina and her fairy friends find the butterflies? Here’s a tip: Each butterfly has its own colourful pattern! Can you see the differences? The wheel of fortune will tell you which butterfly you need to find. Isn’t there a tiny piece of a wing peeking out? Now hurry – surely you want to be the first to reach the castle.

contents:
4 fairy figures, 15 butterflies, 15 leaves, 1 dial, 4 castle cards, instructions

"Some people believe football is a matter of life and death.  I'm very disappointed with that attitude.  I can assure them, it is much, much more important than that."  -  Bill Shankly

In The League players take turns playing cards to attempt to build up an attack culminating in a shot on the opponent's goal or to foil that attack with a well placed tackle or save.  The two-player game pits the players head to head where the 4-player game has two players per team working as a partnership.  Each player starts with 7 cards, replacing cards played with cards from the deck and the game comes to an end after one run through the deck.

The cards are divided into attacking cards eg. Pass, Dribble, Shoot, defending cards eg. Tackle, Save, referee cards, eg. Offside, Penalty, and wonder cards, eg. Wonder Goal, Wonder Save.  The side with possession aims to build up a series of attacking cards leading to a shot thundering past the opponent's keeper, the defending side tries to get possession with a tackle or to get the keeper on the end of the shot with a save card.  Tackles have the risk of being countered by a referee dishing out a yellow or a red card or even a penalty which can only be saved by a Wonder Save.

The game plays in under half an hour and makes for a good filler especially with football fans.

DOMES is a free downloadable game from Gen1400 Gaming.  You can download DOMES from the website www.gen1400.com.

You control a group of Domians trying to survive constant alien attacks.  Each Domian can perform one action per turn.  You decide whether to gather food, fuel, materials, or to repair your DOME.  After the action phase the aliens will fire their lasers trying to destroy your DOME and all of your Domians.

Can you survive 15 turns?
Goal of the game is to get as quickly as possible to the treasure. In order to get there you have to collect some items. Without these items you cannot get past the obstacles.

Kimaloé is the 3rd game from Gameworks Sàrl, after Animalia and Jamaica. As its two predecessors, it is a contract game, this time designed for the Swiss NGO Terre des Hommes and with Children's Rights as background theme.

Kimaloé is a family-oriented game with a flavor of majority and a twist in the scoring system, each player having to manage two scoring pawns that can't be too far away from each other at any given time. Thanks to that little twist, winning the game is more challenging that might appear at first sight.

Release date is 20th November 2008 during the Universal Children's Day.

In It Fits, thinking up a creative answer is just the beginning—now you’ve got to convince everyone else it actually works. Each round, players look at a set of trait cards laid out on the table—things like “has wheels,” “tastes good,” or “makes a loud noise”—and then secretly come up with something, anything, that matches their personal trait card and as many of the public ones as possible.

But here’s the twist: when time’s up, you’ve got to plead your case. You’ll reveal your answer and explain why it fits all those traits... and hope your fellow players agree. If they do, you move ahead on the board. If they challenge you and your logic doesn’t hold up, you might be heading backward instead!

Part party game, part improv challenge, It Fits thrives on wild creativity and good-natured debate. Whether you're trying to justify a "vacuum cleaner" as something “exciting” or insisting a “pineapple” can “float and talk,” the laughs are all in the explanation. Perfect for families, friends, and anyone who enjoys bending the rules of logic with flair.

Similar in spirit to: Perpetual Notion, FitzIt, Such a Thing?, and JaLink!

"Super Juegos" was a pioneer Spanish magazine about both, board and computer games, which was published between 1984-1985. Every issue included a board game inside, with rules and cut-out counters. As far as I know only eight numbers were published, at least in its first epoch (another publication with the same name would appear years later, this time focusing on computer games only).

Issue 3 included "La guerra Irán-Irak", an easy to learn  wargame (two page rules) for two players about the conflict between these two Arabian countries which lasted from 1980 to 1988.

This game was originally published first inside issue 4 of NUMERO UNO magazine in 1980
